citation.article-title: Numerical taxonomy of rapidly growing, scotochromogenic Mycobacteria of the Mycobactrium parafortuitum complex: Mycobacterium austroafricanum sp. nov. and Mycobacterium diernhoferi sp. nov., nom. rev.

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium austroafricanum sp. nov.
Mycobacterium austroafricanum (aus tro af ri ca num. of South Africa)
Acid-fast, rod-shaped cells 2 to 6 μm long and 0.5 μm wide.
Forms mucoid, yellowish pigmented colonies in the dark, showing stronger pigmentation after exposure to light.
Grows at 28 and 37°C, but not at 42°C.
Resistant to NH2OH·HCl at a concentration of 125 μg/ml, but susceptible to NH2OH·HCl at a concentration of 250 μg/ml.
Susceptible to isoniazid (10 μg/ml) and ethambutol(5 μg/ml); resistant to 5% NaCl, p-nitrobenzoic acid (0.5 mg/ml), rifampin (25 μg/ml), and thiophene-2-carboxylic acid hydrozide (1 μg/ml).
Grows on Sauton agar medium containing either 0.1% sodium salicylate, 0.1% NaNO2, or 0.2% picric acid.

Catalase activity (semiquantitative) negative, α-esterase negative, β-esterase positive, β-galactosidase negative, acid phosphatase negative, Tween 80 hydrolysis (after 14 days) negative, and arylsulfatase (after 3 days) positive.
Nicotinamidase and pyrazinamidase positive, but negative for benzamidase, isonicotinamidase, salicylamidase, allantoinase, and succinamidase.

Glutamate and monoethanolamine are utilized as simultaneous nitrogen and carbon sources, but serine, glucosamine, acetamide, benzamide, and trimethylene diamine are not utilized as such sources; acetate, citrate, succinate, malate, pyruvate, or fumarate is utilized as a sole source of carbon in the presence of ammoniacal nitrogen, but benzoate and malonate are not utilized as carbon sources.

The following carbohydrates are utilized as sole sources of carbon in the presence of ammoniacal nitrogen: glucose, fructose, sucrose, ethanol, n-propanol, n-butanol, isobutanol, 1,3-butylene glycol, 2,3-butylene glycol, and xylose.
The following carbohydrates are not utilized as sole sources of carbon: propylene glycol, 1,4-butylene glycol, mannose, galactose, arabinose, rhamnose, trehalose, and sorbitol.
Inositol and mannitol are usually utilized as sole sources of carbon.
